bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Come, Muse, Migrate from Greece and Ionia

div2.note:
16
15
copies
Aug 5 '71 to Lycett & one extra

div1.note: LC catalog clipping. Amanda Gailey: As the clipping indicates, there are two sets of loose proof sheets for "After all, Not to Create only," each consisting of 11 printed sheets followed by a blank sheet. I have photographed only the single sheet that shows a correction in Whitman's hand, page 6 of the first set of sheets.

lg3.l:
In large calm halls, a stately Museum shall teach you the infinite,
solemn lessons of Minerals;

In another, woods, plants, Vegetation shall be illustrated—in an-
other, Animals, animal life, and development.
One stately house shall be the Music House;
Others for other Arts—Learning, the Sciences, shall all be here,

None shall be slighted—none but shall here be honor'd, help'd,
exampled.

This, this and these, America, shall be your Pyramids and Obe-
lisks,
Your Alexandrian Pharos, gardens of Babylon,
The male and female many laboring not,
Shall ever here confront the laboring many,
With precious benefits to both—glory to all,
To thee, America—and thee, eternal Muse.
And here ye shall inhabit, Powerful Matrons!
In your vast state, vaster than all the old;
Echoed through long, long centuries to come,
To sound of different, prouder songs, with stronger themes,
Practical, peaceful life—the people's life—the People themselves,
Lifted, illumin'd, bathed in peace—elate, secure in peace.

lg.l: Away with themes of war! away with War itself!

Hence from my shuddering sight, to never more return, that
show of blacken'd, mutilated corpses!

That hell unpent, and raid of blood—fit for wild tigers, or for
lop
-ear'd
‑tongued
wolves—not reasoning men!

div2.note: Amanda Gailey: Next in the folder is a half-leather bound 8 1/2 x 11 volume containing another set of proof sheets (no corrections), preceded by 10 plates of half-tones and engravings of Whitman, his parents, Emerson, the birthplace, "ancient Whitman burial ground," and "ancient Van Velson burial ground. Also included is a title page in WW's hand: After All, not to Create Only by Walt Whitman Office American Institute New York City 1871. In front of that is the front of a large envelope, cut to size, with Bucke's address, postage, and Whitman's return address--all in Whitman's hand). I have photographed nothing from this volume.
